awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Exploring Fast Mass Transport in Carbon Nanofluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1653767
PI: Duan, Chuanhua

Recent experiments indicate that flow through channels that have nanometer dimensions and smooth carbon surfaces is significantly enhanced compared with flow through channels that have similar or larger dimensions but other types of surfaces. However, the mechanism of flow enhancement in these nanochannels is not fully understood, in part because prior experiments produced highly variable results. This award will support a series of experiments to help reconcile ambiguities in prior experiments and, more importantly, to help uncover the underlying mechanisms of flow enhancement at nanoscale dimensions. Unlike most prior experiments that used flow through arrays of nanochannels in a thin membrane, this project will measure flow of water and ions through individual nanofluidic conduits. A new method of nanochannel design and fabrication, coupled with capillary flow, will be used to directly measure the hydraulic resistance, ionic conductance and mobility, as well as water and ion flow enhancement in single, well-defined carbon nanotubes and graphene nanochannels. Correlations between flow enhancement and material properties, supported by computational modeling, will elucidate key factors that make flow through carbon nanofluidic conduits unique. The results will be useful in designing and fabricating carbon nanofluidic devices and structures for a variety of applications, including water desalination, batteries and fuel cells, lab-on-a-chip, as well as in interpreting certain flows in geology, biology and physiology. The award includes support for educational activities for students at all academic levels. Cartoon animations and hands-on lab kits that illustrate the unique physics of flow at the nanoscale will be developed for use by K-12 students. The project will provide opportunities for undergraduates, especially those from underrepresented groups, to participate in the research. 

Since research using membranes consisting of multi-conduit carbon nanotubes or graphene nanochannels introduces ambiguities due to conduit-size polydispersity, this award will study water and ion transport in single carbon nanotubes and graphene nanochannels with well-defined sizes, surface properties and barrier materials. The experiments will test the hypothesis that fast mass transport of water and ions in these channels results from unique surface-water and surface-ion interactions, which strongly depend on the substrate or barrier material as well as on the confinement and surface properties of these carbon nanofluidic conduits. Experimental measurements will be compared with molecular dynamics simulations that consider explicitly effects of substrate/barrier material, surface charge, and ion-water interactions. The carbon nanofluidic devices fabricated in this project will also provide investigators a platform to study selective ion and gas transport, which could not only improve understanding of carbon nanofluidics, but also expand its practical applications to chemical and biological separations processes.

por.por_cntn:
Fast mass transport in carbon nanofluidic structures (i.e., nanoporous membranes and/or fluidic devices containing nanoconduits with atomically smooth carbon surfaces) have been reported over the last two decades, showing great potential for applications in energy conversion/storage, water desalination and biosensing/separation. However, the measured enhancement factor has been largely scattered and the underlying mechanisms for transport enhancement (and the large variation) remain elusive due to ambiguity in previous experimental measurements.

In this CAREER proposal, we aimed to use single nanofluidic conduits with well-defined geometries and surface properties to systematically measure and understand fast mass transport in nanofluidics. We studied three types of fast mass transport, including fast water transport in graphene nanoslits, enhanced evaporation in graphene nanopores and fast drying in 2-D nanochannels.

We first studied fast water transport in graphene nanoslits (Figure 1) [1]. We developed a new optical measurement technique that can measure the hydraulic resistance and the slip length of single graphene nanochannels using capillary flow and a hybrid nanochannel design [1,2]. Our results reveal that the slip length of graphene in the graphene nanoslits has an average value of 16 nm and shows a large variation from 0 to 200 nm regardless of the channel height. We further found that this wide distribution of the slip length results from different surface charge densities of graphene as well as different interactions between graphene and its underlying substrate. To further separate these contributions for fast mass transport, we developed a new method based on current monitoring to measure surface charge density in the nanochannel without estimating the ion diffusivity [3]. 

In addition to fast water transport, we also studied enhanced evaporation from graphene nanopores [4]. We integrated graphene nanopores into nanochannels and used the resulting 3-D nanofluidic devices to accurately measure water evaporation from single nanopores. Our results showed that evaporation flux from graphene nanpores shows a large variation, and the average value is much higher than that from silicon-nitirid nanopores with the same diameter. We found that the enhanced evaporation and the large variation can be explained by the ultra-thin thickness of graphene nanopores and the effect of unique edge-water interactions on the evaporation coefficient. Beside these experimental studies, we also found that surface charges can change the evaporation area and thus enhance evaporation through numerical simulation [5].

Besides enhanced water flow and evaporation, we studied fast drying in nanochannels with height ranging from 29 to 122 nm [6]. Two different drying behaviors are discovered in such nanoconfinements: continuous meniscus receding and discontinuous meniscus receding due to liquid bridge formation ahead of the meniscus, albeit similar drying rates. Our results show that both corner flow and vapor diffusion play important roles on fast water drying in nanochannels. Our findings further indicate that water vapor diffusion in nanoscale confinements can still be described by the classic Knudsen diffusion theory.

Overall new insights gained from these fast mass transport studies in nanochannels/nanopores not only provide a new level of understanding, but also provide design guidelines for novel graphene-based nanoporous membranes for large-scale energy/water related applications, such as water desalination and electronic cooling. The new measurement techniques developed can also be used as standard methods for flow characterization of single nanoconduits and nanoporous materials in other nanofluidics-related disciplines, including soil science, colloid chemistry, biology and physiology. In addition, the new fabrication processes developed can be used to create other 3-D nanofluidic devices or 3-D MEMS/NEMS devices.

From an education standpoint, our objective was to convey the excitement and relevance of nanofluidics to students and teachers with diverse backgrounds. We used simple schematics and animation with water molecules and ions as the cartoon characters to help explain transport mechanisms and disseminate latest research progress in seminars and conferences. We offered a graduate level course titled "Introduction to Micro/Nanofluidics" to BU ENG graduate students and senior undergraduates. We partnered with several education/outreach programs at BU to provide research opportunities and summer internshipsrelated to nanofluidics to female and underrepresented undergraduates and high-school students/teachers. Finally, we successfully organized an international symposium titled "2-D Nanomaterials-Based Nanofluidics" in 2019 MRS Fall meeting.

References:

[1]  Q. Xie, M. Alibakhshi, S. Jiao, Z. Xu, M. Hempel, J. Kong, H.G. Park and C. Duan, “Fast Water Transport in Graphene Nanochannels”, Nature Nanotechnology, vol. 13, pp. 238-245, (2018). 

[2] J. Zhong, M.A. Alibakhshi, Q. Xu, J. Riordon, Y. Xu, C. Duan and D. Sinton, Accounts of Chemical Research, 53 (2), 347-357, (2020).

[3] S. Xiao, Q. Xie*, Z. Wollman* and C. Duan, Microfluidics and Nanofluidics, 26, 1-15, (2022).

[4] S. Xiao, K. Meng, Q. Xie, L. Zhai, Z. Xu, H. Wang and C. Duan, Cell Reports Physics Science, 100900, (2022).

[5] C.Y. Chou and C. Duan, International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer, 204, 123865, (2023).

[6] Q. Xie, S. Xiao and C. Duan, Langmuir, 33, 395-8403, (2017).
